I'm a Christian, so I don't believe in that kind of
stuff either.  But it's best not to underestimate what
your subconcious does if it's been influenced in the
wrong way.  As much as I hate to admit it that's
almost certainly the case with stigmata (otherwise the
wounds would be in the wrists, the people in the movie
got it wrong, real life cases of stigmata for some
bizarre reason had them appearing in the hands).

--- cardhead649 <cardhead649@...> wrote:
> Oh, for the love of ... I won't say it.
> 
> What the hell, I will anyway:
> 
> I can't believe people are so stupid, so utterly
> devoid of 
> intelligence, that they'll believe the total
> bullshit they find in 
> these chain letters.
> 
> CASE 1:
> 
> Cardhead opens his mailbox, finding a chain letter
> that 
> promises "luck", something that doesn't exist other
> than as part of 
> superstition.  Cardhead deletes the message without
> even reading the 
> entire intro, let alone the message itself.  Weeks
> pass and nothing, 
> repeat NOTHING, happens.  Situation repeats every
> now and again, as 
> online contacts fall for the same old "true story"
> approach.  CASE 
> CLOSED.
> 
> --- In nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com, Kyle Stewart
> <dewboy30816@y...> wrote:
> > A somewhat silly way to get out of it I know, but
> hey
> > I don't wanna' get hit by a hit and run driver,
> and I
> > don't HAVE the e-mail address of 10 friends not on
> > this site (I could probably scrong up 3 or 4).
> > 
> > Note: forwarded message attached.
> > 
> 
>
